awd_titl_txt: Monitoring the Health of Structural Systems from the Geometry of Sensor Traces
awd_abstract_narration:
Deterioration from the passage of time and from exposure to large loading events can reduce the safety of structural systems. The effectiveness and efficiency of interventions to maintain adequate reliability depend on the available information, and the objective of structural monitoring is to provide it. Attempts to characterize deterioration by tracking resonant frequencies has had limited success due to small sensitivity of the features relative to their irreducible variability. This award supports research on an entirely different paradigm: one where monitoring is carried out not by inspection of resonant frequencies, but by examination of a geometric object built from measurements obtained in closed-loop operation. Gains, over the path so far pursued, come from the ability to "tune" the monitored object by selection of the control laws. The results from this research will open a new path for developing structural health monitoring systems. This new path, and the progress that will come from it, will benefit the US economy by reducing the cost of inspections, by advancing the practice of condition based maintenance, and, ultimately, by reducing the life cycle cost of structural systems. The research in this project sits at the intersection of several disciplines and this aspect is exploited in an educational component designed to inspire students and young researchers from various fields. 

The research in this award casts the monitoring problem as that of tracking the geometry of an object generated by trajectories that are traversed as the system operates autonomously under nonlinear feedback. In contrast with linear feedback, which retains the classical monitoring structure, and thus infers about changes from eigenvalues, nonlinear feedback attempts to map the reference state to the geometry of an attractor and focuses on how system changes affect the resulting manifold. Theory to guide how to specify the nonlinear control so the system has a stable attractor, with a predictable basin of attraction, is currently lacking. The simulation-guided, theoretical research that is central to this work is intended to contribute in filling this knowledge gap. The research tackles also the question of how to select the state from where the system is "launched" so the demands on the necessary actuation is minimized; minimization of the infinity norm of the actuation being important to the practicality of the investigated paradigm. Albeit the optimal sensor and actuator placement problems are not explicitly included in the scope of the project, exploratory work in both of these issues is planned.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: SENSORS AND SENSOR SYSTEMS FOR CIS

por.por_cntn:
Structures can deteriorate from aging or suffer damage from exposure to extreme loading events and may require interventions to ensure reliable performance throughout their service life. The structural condition has traditionally been ascertained from visual inspections, but the subjectivity and limitations of this approach are well-recognized and much research on methods that can take advantage of sensor data has been carried out. Techniques to inspect small areas, known as local techniques, are now well-developed but methods to identify damage where the general location is unknown are less established. Most methods that attempt to solve the global damage detection problem use vibrations induced by ambient sources like wind or traffic but there are also cases where vibrations are forced by introducing excitation with hydraulic or other type of actuators. When actuators are used, and the forces do not depend on the vibrations themselves, the system is said to operate in open-loop and otherwise the operating mode is in closed-loop. This project examined the closed-loop operating alternative for structural health monitoring purposes using linear and nonlinear feedback strategies.

The objective of using feedback in interrogation is to increase the information that measurements carry on parameters. When the feedback depends linearly on the measurements the objective is pursued by selecting the controller to make the sensitivity of the closed-loop natural frequencies larger than in the open-loop with the possibility for further improvement by aggregation of results from different controllers. A key result from this project is the observation that the effects of linear feedback on the eigenstructure can be realized by signal processing operations on open-loop recorded data. The virtual implementation is possible because the interrogation is carried out off-line and because what matters is not what the closed-loop eigenstructure is (since response adjustment is not the objective) but what the identification algorithm "thinks it is". In addition to the merit of eliminating the cost of the real time operation, the virtual implementation removes stability and hardware related constraints from consideration and thus simplifies the design of the controller. The virtual implementation of linear output feedback formulated in this project switches input-output interrogation from a methodology where the only freedom was in the placement of sensors to an approach where sensitivities can be tailored to specific objectives.

When the feedback is nonlinear the objective is to render the structural behavior nonlinear (even though the open-loop is linear) so changes in patterns that are exclusive to nonlinear dynamics become available for damage characterization. In this portion of the project the focus was placed on finding a feedback law for which the autonomous (unforced) structural response is a unique periodic orbit and the period of this orbit, also known as a limit cycle, was selected as the feature for tracking damage. Results on the merit of this strategy were mixed. Specifically, while it was found that the limit cycle period could be made highly sensitive to damage in the proximity of the actuator, the sensitivity decreased with distance and for some configurations the approach proved ineffective over important portions of the domain. While it is possible to cover the full domain by using multiple actuators, this alternative was not judged competitive on account of cost and complexity and was not pursued. On the positive side, in structures for which a single actuator suffices the limit cycle period scheme offers some attractive features. Namely, the approach operates without a model and discrimination between no damage and damage is carried out by simple inspection of the sensor traces.

In addition to the technical work this project provided the opportunity to host two high-school students from Belmont MA in an internship at the PI's dynamic and identification lab on the summer of 2019 for six weeks.  During this time the students learned about the essence of the project, became quite proficient in some computational software and helped in simulation related work. The enthusiasm of one of the students, who has decided to apply to engineering schools next year, proved most rewarding.
